articles.headline: Amazon Updates Its Kindle Line of E-Readers
articles.snippet: With a new version of the Kindle Fire nearly as large as the iPad that undercuts its price by $200, Amazon made its challenge to Apple a little more serious.
articles.abstract: With a new version of the Kindle Fire nearly as large as the iPad that undercuts its price by $200, Amazon made its challenge to Apple a little more serious.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Amazon announced a barrage of new tablets and e-readers on Thursday that makes its challenge to Apple’s iPad a little more serious.

articles.headline: Kansas City Bishop Convicted of Shielding Pedophile Priest
articles.snippet: Bishop Robert W. Finn was sentenced to two years of court-supervised probation for failing to report suspected child abuse.
articles.abstract: Bishop Robert W. Finn was sentenced to two years of court-supervised probation for failing to report suspected child abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — A Roman Catholic bishop was found guilty on Thursday of failing to report suspected child abuse, becoming the first American bishop in the decades-long sexual abuse scandal to be convicted of shielding a pedophile priest.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Web Businessman Sentenced for Threats
articles.snippet: Vitaly Borker, who terrified customers of his online eyewear store, DecorMyEyes, was sentenced to four years in federal prison and ordered to pay $100,000.
articles.abstract: Vitaly Borker, who terrified customers of his online eyewear store, DecorMyEyes, was sentenced to four years in federal prison and ordered to pay $100,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who terrified customers of his online eyewear store with threats of violence, including rape, was sentenced on Thursday to four years in federal prison and ordered to pay nearly $100,000 in restitution and fines.

articles.headline: Obama Makes Case for 2nd Term: ‘Harder’ Path to ‘Better Place’
articles.snippet: Accepting the Democratic nomination for a second term, President Obama argued, “it will take more than a few years for us to solve challenges that have built up over decades.”
articles.abstract: Accepting the Democratic nomination for a second term, President Obama argued, “it will take more than a few years for us to solve challenges that have built up over decades.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — President Obama accepted the Democratic nomination for a second term on Thursday night, making a forceful argument that he had rescued the economy from disaster and ushered in a recovery that would be imperiled by a return to Republican stewardship.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Joblessness May Undermine Obama Convention Bump
articles.snippet: For President Obama, the August employment report, which showed fewer new jobs than expected, was a blunt reminder of the forces working against him as his convention closed.
articles.abstract: For President Obama, the August employment report, which showed fewer new jobs than expected, was a blunt reminder of the forces working against him as his convention closed.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Presidential candidates can usually count on luxuriating in a few days of warm feelings from their convention as they ride the high generated by impassioned supporters and cross their fingers for rising poll numbers.

articles.headline: Apple Plans Web Radio Challenge to Pandora
articles.snippet: Apple is in the early stages of negotiating with the major record labels for a service that would send streams of music customized to users’ tastes.
articles.abstract: Apple is in the early stages of negotiating with the major record labels for a service that would send streams of music customized to users’ tastes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that could shake up the growing field of Internet radio, Apple plans to develop a service that would compete with Pandora Media by sending streams of music customized to users’ tastes, three people briefed on the plans said late Thursday.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Glencore’s Bid to Buy Xstrata Is Increased at the 11th Hour
articles.snippet: Glencore International, the world’s biggest commodities-trading company, sweetened its offer for Xstrata in a last-minute bid to save the mega-merger.
articles.abstract: Glencore International, the world’s biggest commodities-trading company, sweetened its offer for Xstrata in a last-minute bid to save the mega-merger.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Glencore, the world’s largest commodities trader, saved its megamerger with Xstrata from collapse on Friday by sweetening its offer for the large multinational mining company. But the deal still remains in limbo after Xstrata raised concerns about the revised proposal.

articles.headline: Hiring Slows in U.S., Putting Pressure on Obama and Fed
articles.snippet: The economy added 96,000 jobs in August, well below expectations, raising the pressure on the White House and strengthening the argument for action by the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: The economy added 96,000 jobs in August, well below expectations, raising the pressure on the White House and strengthening the argument for action by the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s employers eased up on hiring in August, making it clear that the economy was stuck in low gear.
